Mas -
looking forward to seeing your new treasures. For other folks I  
pos=
ted some photos to my Nihonto@ foto folder since I had lots of  
room there=
. Not a lot of pics really but I didn't have time to take  
pictures while =
simultaneously picking up everything on all the tables...
-t

On Aug 20, 20=
07, at 12:25 PM, kiwi57 KAWAI wrote:

>
> Hey Tom,
>
> I kinda went into a =
Nihonto feeding frenzy and bought a sword,  
> koshirae and
> 3 tsuba.  I s=
hould never have left the front check-in table......   
> But I
> agree wit=
h your statement about enjoying good company the whole  
> weekend.  I
> en=
joyed that most of all.
>
> I have a Kawai Hisayoshi in my lineage, but I'm=
 wondering if  
> Hisayuki is
> there also...  I have a family scroll that =
shows my family history  
> dating
> back to around the beginning of the He=
ian Period which states that  
> I am
> descended from Taira Kiyomori.  I'm=
 bringing it to club meeting  
> because I
> talked to Fred at the show and=
 want some clarification about what  
> it says.
>

n out a questionaire/feedback form when someone
> registers for a table?  O=
r maybe hand them out to people before the  
> end of

dback about the show and if we can improve on

they may have (including accomdations)?  This

us make the show even better.  Just thinking out loud...........

>> Elliott et al-
>> 	D=
espite light sales activity no one I talked to was disappointed
>> with thi=
s years show. The tables were all full, unlike laste year
>> when storms ba=
ck east prevented some from attending. There were
>> several Japanese with =
tables set up that had not been here in the
>> recent past, Most notably Ao=
i Arts. There were exceptional swords,
>> and lots of average blades though=
 maybe not as many swords overall
>> compared to last year. two things of n=
ote were the number of Gassan
>> works for sale, there were a half dozen po=
lished and papered pieces
>> scattered through out the show room and a real=
 chance to study
>> Sadakazu, Sadakatsu and others. Also there were many mo=
re koshirae of
>> exceptional quality and interest and I enjoyed quite a bi=
t of my time
>> pouring over these.
>> 	The NTHK presented the Swords and F=
ittings of Mino Province, the
>> Naginata seen below is from that exhibit. =
The NBTHK did a
>> presentation of Tanto, 13 total as I recall, from Awatag=
uchi Hisakuni
>> to Gassan Sadakazu. The Soshu Yukimitsu tanti which was nu=
mber two on
>> the table was my pick for best of show. There was a Soshu Hi=
romasa
>> Otanto (kowakizashi) in the middle of the pack that was in an old=
er
>> polish which was a bit scuffed up but this did not prevent one from
>=
> seeing the quality, a fine example of the period and not the kind of
>> k=
oto we usually see around here.
>> 	There was an NBTHK Kantei-kai as well. =
With a Yosozaemon Suksada
>> yoroidoshi and a Kawai Hisayuki katana being t=
he stand-outs. The
>> Kawai blade was presented by the First Japanese Ambas=
sadors to the US
>> to their American chaperone and it is still held in the=
 same family.
>> A real treasure.
>> 	I bought some books as one might expe=
ct, sold very few that I
>> brought with me but I learned lots and enjoyed =
good company all
>> weekend. I am sure we'll here more from others as they =
get back to
>> their homes from way out west...
>> -t
